data.title: Usher has a Super Bowl-worthy legacy. Why donâ€™t people act like it?
data.meta_description: Put some respect on Usherâ€™s name.
data.text:
Across his 30-year career, Usher has been deemed the â€œKing of R&Bâ€ and a â€œlegendâ€ for his catalog of Top 10 hits, smooth dance breaks, life-changing serenades, and lighthearted, meme-worthy energy. And yet, fans and music experts still have to explain why the superstar is a big deal ahead of his career-defining Super Bowl moment.

In September, Usher surprised his younger self with the news that heâ€™d be performing during the major event. A promotional video following the NFLâ€™s announcement shows present-day Usher calling Usher from the 2004 â€œConfessions Pt. IIâ€ music video to deliver the big news. â€œStop playinâ€™ with me,â€ the younger Usher responds. Many saw the eight-time Grammy-winning singer as an obvious, even overdue, choice. Fans rejoiced, posting â€œYeahhhh!â€ (a nod to Usherâ€™s 2004 hit featuring rappers Lil Jon and Ludacris) and jokingly claiming to be prepping the Y2K outfits theyâ€™ll wear to their living rooms to watch one of the countryâ€™s biggest stars hit the NFL stage.

But critics also spoke out. On a Reddit post about the announcement, a user commented, â€œWow, this would have been really exciting news 20 years agoâ€ and received nearly 4,000 upvotes. Another wrote, â€œSeriously the best they could do?â€ On X, one user wrote ahead of the announcement, â€œI know yâ€™all think Usher should perform the next SB but I donâ€™t think he has enough pop/hip-hop hits.â€

More recently, as Taylor Swiftâ€™s romance with Travis Kelce â€” who will play in the big game â€” continues to dominate the news cycle, Swifties have demanded that Usher bring Swift onstage. Some have argued the attention on the Eras star is already dimming Usherâ€™s moment.

One could say that the mixed reactions ahead of Usherâ€™s show are typical responses for any Super Bowl announcement: One artist, or genre, canâ€™t please the more than 100 million viewers who tune in. But experts told Vox that the critics questioning Usherâ€™s impact and relevance are illustrating something much bigger: Itâ€™s a reaction thatâ€™s indicative of racial, generational, and cultural divides in America.

â€œThe discourse is really showing how we live in two different Americas,â€ said Taylor Crumpton, a writer and culture critic who has written extensively about the return of R&B. â€œThereâ€™s a [contingent] of people who feel that Usher getting a Super Bowl is way overdue. Itâ€™s time to give him his flowers.â€

What the perfect Super Bowl halftime star needs

An event as massive as the Super Bowl halftime show requires an artist with a deep catalog of well-known hits, dedicated fans, and widespread appeal. They must be able to speak to the NFLâ€™s diverse and enormous audience. Some 118.7 million people tuned in to the 2023 halftime show, the most viewers in the showâ€™s history.

Usher has performed at the Super Bowl before â€” in 2011, alongside the headlining Black Eyed Peas, to sing â€œOMG,â€ his 2010 hit featuring will.i.am. In 2024, during Black History Month, heâ€™ll perform a career retrospective and honor the Black artists who came before him.

â€œItâ€™s an honor of a lifetime to finally check a Super Bowl performance off my bucket list. I canâ€™t wait to bring the world a show unlike anything else theyâ€™ve seen from me before,â€ the 45-year-old veteran entertainer said in a statement at the time of the announcement.

Some are already saying that the halftime performance is a part of Usherâ€™s renaissance, but others see the moment as confirmation of what the star has been giving fans all along.

â€œI donâ€™t think itâ€™s so much a renaissance moment as it is a validation moment,â€ said Naima Cochrane, culture journalist and professor at NYUâ€™s Clive Davis Institute of Recorded Music. â€œUsherâ€™s been Usher. He has a longevity and consistency of brand and presence that is unmatched in R&B.â€

Having the King of R&B headline footballâ€™s main event makes sense for the NFL in 2024.

Back in the summer of 2019, Roc Nation, Jay-Zâ€™s entertainment company, struck a deal with the league to produce the Super Bowl halftime show. When the deal went through, many speculated that the NFL signed it to distract from its racist history and present and to quell uproar over its treatment of Colin Kaepernick. Critics see Usherâ€™s performance as somewhat linked to this effort.

Since 2019, Roc Nation has selected a diverse slate of artists, a mix of icons and popular newcomers with current hits. There was Shakira and Jennifer Lopez in 2020; The Weeknd the following year; a hip-hop-themed showcase for the genreâ€™s 50th anniversary featuring Dr. Dre, Snoop Dogg, Eminem, Mary J. Blige, and Kendrick Lamar in 2022; and last yearâ€™s performance by Rihanna. It was a reset from over a decade of often lackluster shows.

Following 2004â€™s wardrobe malfunction with Justin Timberlake and Janet Jackson â€” which received more than half a million Federal Communications Commission complaints â€” the NFL parted ways with producer MTV and brought on Paul McCartney, the Rolling Stones, Prince, Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers, Bruce Springsteen and the E Street Band, and The Who over the next six years, hoping to play it safe. The mostly white male â€œclassicâ€ artists were an attempt to appease viewers who complained that the show had gone astray, but the shows became something of a joke for featuring what the Washington Post called â€œover-the-hill rockers.â€

â€œSince MTV stopped doing the halftime show, thereâ€™s never really been any consistency with who is selected for the act,â€ said Cochrane. â€œI think the Super Bowl just chooses to focus on different things at different times.â€

In 2024, the league and its affiliates have decided to focus on Usher. And itâ€™s time to put some respect on his name.

People have tried to deny Usherâ€™s legacy

Usher has most recently been crowned the â€œNew King of Vegas,â€ the city where heâ€™ll perform on the Super Bowl stage at Allegiant Stadium.

Having the King of R&B headline footballâ€™s main event makes sense for the NFL in 2024

He began a residency at the Colosseum at Caesars Palace in 2021 and a year later moved to the Park MGM, where tickets consistently sold out. The show was extended multiple times until the end of 2023, when Usher wrapped it up after 100 performances. The residency stage was part strip club, part roller skating rink, part parade, and part jazz club, and his decades-spanning career prepared him well for it.

Before arriving in Las Vegas, it had been six years since Usher was on tour. He told GQ, â€œI really wanted to give women something to look forward to, something to come here to Las Vegas with their friends for. Theyâ€™ve been saving up all year and were able to manage to get away from their kids or get away from their problems.â€

The show grew popular as countless celebrities (Keke Palmer, various Kardashians, LeBron James, Jennifer Lopez, Doja Cat, Zendaya and Tom Holland, Issa Rae, and more) stopped by and videos of the superstar serenading thirsty audience members went viral. In a number of videos, fans could be seen running up to touch Usher as he walked through the crowd singing â€œHey Daddy (Daddyâ€™s Home).â€

Usherâ€™s popular songs carried the show. Out of his 18 Billboard Top 10 hits, a whopping nine of them (â€œNice & Slow,â€ â€œU Remind Me,â€ â€œYeah!,â€ â€œU Got It Bad,â€ â€œConfessions Part II,â€ â€œBurn,â€ â€œMy Boo,â€ â€œLove in This Club,â€ and â€œOMGâ€) made it to No. 1. He has 53 songs that made it to the Billboard Hot 100, and by some estimates he has sold over 100 million records in his career. His stage presence has earned dozens of awards, including Grammys, Critics Choice Awards, BET and MTV Music Awards, and NAACP Image Awards.

Cochrane said that Usherâ€™s traditional training is what makes him unmatched today.

â€œHe has always been a consummate performer, one of the last of his school who really got to sit at the feet of the greats, directly learn from them, and apply it,â€ she said. The star names icons like Luther Vandross, Marvin Gaye, Michael Jackson, Teddy Pendergrass, and more as his inspirations. â€œHeâ€™s in the last of the classes who were in vocal training, underwent artist development, or were in the studio learning their stage shows. He is an entertainer, and we donâ€™t have a lot of those anymore.â€

Usherâ€™s roles and guest appearances on various reality TV programs expanded his stardom. He joined fellow music icons Shakira, Adam Levine, and Blake Shelton on season four of The Voice as a coach. He returned in season six, leading his team to victory, and appeared on later seasons as a leading coach and adviser. His â€œwatch thisâ€ moment during his NPR Tiny Desk concert in 2022, in which he placed his fingers across his face to the beat and became a viral meme, endeared him to viewers and reminded everyone of his charm.

While Usherâ€™s career took a dip in the 2010s when changes at Billboard tested R&Bâ€™s popularity, after dominating the 1990s and aughts, he remained relevant, critics say. â€œThe album that people point to as his flopâ€ â€” Raymond v. Raymond â€” â€œwas still a platinum album. He has had moments where heâ€™s less consistent, but heâ€™s always been present and relevant,â€ Cochrane said. â€œWe take him for granted. Usher is doing collaborations with these younger artists. Heâ€™s sampling his own work. How many people get to do that?â€

Usherâ€™s traditional training is what makes him unmatched today

The Super Bowl announcement isnâ€™t the first time Usherâ€™s legacy has been questioned. During online debates about who would make a good matchup for the popular pandemic Verzuz battles, commentators cast doubt on Usherâ€™s record, uncertain heâ€™d be able to win over Chris Brown. And in the early 2000s, some people pitted Usher against Justin Timberlake, seeing them as rivals.

With the halftime show, some people have questioned Usherâ€™s crossover appeal â€” whether he can appeal to audiences who love pop and also hip-hop. But it is his crossover appeal that makes him the no-brainer choice for the Super Bowl, critics told Vox.

â€œGen Z may think of Usher as a person who signed Justin Bieber, whereas earlier generations see him as a king with crossover appeal â€” working not only in music but also in TV and film,â€ said Crumpton. â€œEvery suburban soccer mom feels a type of way when â€˜Yeah!â€™ comes on.â€

Usher just released his ninth studio album, Coming Home, a few days after announcing a new world tour and a few days ahead of the big game. Itâ€™s a medley of Afrobeats hits featuring new artists, across 20 tracks.

But the star made it clear that his performance at Super Bowl LVIII will focus on the impact of Black R&B artists of the past.

â€œTo have R&B have the main stage at the Super Bowl, itâ€™s a major thing for me,â€ he said in an interview with Good Morning America. â€œI think about what our country has kind of represented for Black artists having to at some point go through kitchens to even be able to perform for an audience, but they had to leave back through that same door [and] fear for their lives as they went to the next state to do the same thing. So Iâ€™m coming through the front door with this one. I think about all of the R&B performers who I carry in this moment.â€

In the short 13-minute show, critics expect Usher to bring the energy, be elaborate, but most of all represent where heâ€™s from.

â€œHeâ€™s going to elevate Black people in Atlanta and Black people in the South,â€ said Crumpton. â€œThatâ€™s why it will be so monumental and invigorating to see.â€
